intro: Thladiantha hookeri var. heptadactyla, commonly known as the seven-fingered bittersweet, is a climbing plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Solanaceae, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its woody stems and compound leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers followed by orange-red berries that contain toxic compounds. Its foliage and fruit are often used in traditional medicine, though caution is required due to its poisonous nature. The varietal name "heptadactyla" refers to the seven leaflets on its compound leaves.
